questions.question_text:
A developer needs to modify an application architecture to meet new functional requirements. Application data is stored in Amazon DynamoDB and processed for analysis in a nightly batch. The system analysts do not want to wait until the next day to view the processed data and have asked to have it available in near-real time.

Which application architecture pattern would enable the data to be processed as it is received?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think A, don't need to wait schedule , message ,batch, just focus on real-time event-trigger and process

Odd question. 

Let's have a look at "fan-out" definition: "In message-oriented middleware solutions, fan-out is a messaging pattern used to model an information exchange that implies the delivery (or spreading) of a message to one or multiple destinations possibly in parallel, and not halting the process that executes the messaging to wait for any response to that message". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan-out_(software)

Can't choose between A and C.

Selected Answer: A
Event driven architecture is the correct answer
I found some useful explanations of event driven arch. https://ably.com/blog/introduction-event-driven-architecture

I think it should be D!
A-Event Driven archi' are triggered to run when there is an event like a notification, data push etc.
B-Client-Server does not make sense at all
C-Fan-out is also similar to A, like SQS-SNS fanout archi' when SNS receives a notificaiton and SQS will process the data .
The question asks about analysis to be done in the night batch and to be processed by the next day. Hence Scheduling it using CRON jobs, Eventbridge, Lambda Functions can be used
This question was on the exam today (Feb 2023)
A it is

Selected Answer: A
Its A the others are not options

Selected Answer: A
AAAAAAA

I choose A.
Event driven = real time

Selected Answer: A
i think A is the only real driven
A event-driven

questions.question_text:
A company is migrating a web application from on premises to AWS. The company needs to move session storage from the application code to a shared service as part of the migration. The session storage data must be encrypted at rest.

Which AWS services meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Strictly memcached has no rest ( its all in memory with no persistance )

Selected Answer: AE
We can save session storage on Elastic Cache or DynamoDB as well. Since the data must be encrypted, we have to choose ElasticCache for Redis (rather than Memcached) and also Amazon DynamoDB since it support encryption at rest with KMS. So, A and E are the correct ones

comments.content: *B- ElastiCache Memcached does not support encryption at rest*

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
the correct answers are A. Amazon ElastiCache for Redis and E. Amazon DynamoDB.
C. ElastiCache Memcached does not support encryption at rest

Selected Answer: AE
A and E

A : encrypt at rest
E: Encrypt at rest too
A and E

Selected Answer: AE
A and E
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/amazon-elasticache-now-supports-encryption-for-elasticache-for-redis/

comments.content:
ElastiCache Memcached can be used for session storage. However, the question asks encryption at rest while ElastiCache Memcached only supports encryption in-transit

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonElastiCache/latest/mem-ug/in-transit-encryption-mc.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
A) ElastiCache for Redis is always a good option as a distributed cache for session management - https://aws.amazon.com/getting-started/hands-on/building-fast-session-caching-with-amazon-elasticache-for-redis/
It also supports encrypt at rest - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonElastiCache/latest/red-ug/at-rest-encryption.html

E) DynamoDB is also common to store session state with TTL support. And all user data stored in Amazon DynamoDB is fully encrypted at rest - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/EncryptionAtRest.html

comments.content: Amazon ElastiCache for Memcached now supports encryption of data in transit

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Of course, it is A and B

Selected Answer: AD
Redis and DynamoDB. I don't understand why so many vote for A&B. What should Memcache be useful for in this scenario ? Hopefully somebody can unswer this. Redis is without a doubt right...

Selected Answer: AE
ElasticCache Redis can store session obj and has high availability and can be encrypted. DynamoDb is encrypted by default and its speed can used for storing session info

Selected Answer: A
AAAAAA

Selected Answer: AB
A and B

Selected Answer: AB
A and B

A and could it be D ?
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-sdk-php/v2/guide/feature-dynamodb-session-handler.htmlhttps://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/EncryptionAtRest.html

A, B
Only caching/encrypting options I see to choose from
I believe it's A and E

Selected Answer: A
reddis is encrypted at rest but i can only see memcache encrypted at transit. 

https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2022/05/amazon-elasticache-memcached-supports-encryption-data-transit/

A, B Amazon ElastiCache for Redis and Memcached
https://aws.amazon.com/caching/session-management/

questions.question_text:
A gaming application stores scores for players in an Amazon DynamoDB table that has four attributes user_id, user_name, user_score and user_rank. The users are allowed to update their names only. A user is authenticated by web identity federation.

Which set of conditions should be added in the policy attached to the role for the dynamodb:PutItem API call?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"If you use dynamodb:Attributes, you must specify the names of all of the primary key and index key attributes for the table and any secondary indexes that are listed in the policy. Otherwise, DynamoDB can't use these key attributes to perform the requested action."

that makes sense, can't update user_name without user_id

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer. The Leading key allows users to access only the items where the partition key value matches their user ID. And as Attribute value we set user_name because we want that the userID is able to update only his username

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/specifying-conditions.html

The question "Which set of conditions should be added in the policy attached to the role for the dynamodb:PutItem API call?" shouldn't ask about UpdateItem? Is it a typo or is it ok? If it is all right, then why?
This question was on the exam today (Feb 2023)

comments.content: Was this the new DVA-CO2 Exam?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A it is.
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
Choosing A

I choose A,
the identifier is the user id, and attribute that can be changed is the user_name

A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/specifying-conditions.html

questions.question_text:
A company is hosting a workshop for external users and wants to share the reference documents with the external users for 7 days. The company stores the reference documents in an Amazon S3 bucket that the company owns.

What is the MOST secure way to share the documents with the external users?

choices.D: Create a role that has read-only access to the S3 bucket. Share the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of this role with the external users.
choices.A: Use S3 presigned URLs to share the documents with the external users. Set an expiration time of 7 days.
choices.C: Create temporary IAM users that have read-only access to the S3 bucket. Share the access keys with the external users. Expire the credentials after 7 days.
choices.B: Move the documents to an Amazon WorkDocs folder Share the links of the WorkDocs folder with the external users.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Definitely A. Presigned URLs are intended for temporary access

Selected Answer: A
A. Use S3 presigned URLs to share the documents with the external users. Set an expiration time of 7 days. 
Is the most secure way to guarantee access to S3 and it's possible to estabilish an expiration

Selected Answer: A
AAAAAAA

A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/ShareObjectPreSignedURL.html
A-pre-signed URL's

choices.C: Store the objects by using object key names distributed across multiple prefixes.
choices.A: Store the objects by using S3 Intelligent-Tiering.
choices.B: Store the objects at the root of the S3 bucket.
choices.D: Store each object with an object tag named "prefix" that contains a unique value.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Prefix should be a correct answer:
For example, your application can achieve at least 3,500 PUT/COPY/POST/DELETE or 5,500 GET/HEAD requests per second per partitioned prefix. There are no limits to the number of prefixes in a bucket. You can increase your read or write performance by using parallelization. For example, if you create 10 prefixes in an Amazon S3 bucket to parallelize reads, you could scale your read performance to 55,000 read requests per second

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/optimizing-performance.html

Selected Answer: C
Chatgpt and Google Gemini Agree with C

Selected Answer: C
like object-key name : newFolder/folder1/folder2

According to Amazon S3 documentation, your application can achieve at least 3,500 PUT/COPY/POST/DELETE or 5,500 GET/HEAD requests per second per partitioned prefix. There are no limits to the number of prefixes in a bucket. You can increase your read or write performance by using parallelization1.

Based on this information, the correct answer would be C. Store the objects by using object key names distributed across multiple prefixes
ccccccc
C. Using prefix is better option

C.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/optimizing-performance.html

Selected Answer: C
C https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/optimizing-performance.html

Selected Answer: A
i chose A because of the phrase: request rate which denotes that some items are more frequently accessed than others. https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2018/11/s3-intelligent-tiering/

comments.content: please disregard my answer- i must have been drunk while answering. lol. i go with C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C

questions.question_text:
A developer is storing many objects in a single Amazon S3 bucket. The developer needs to optimize the S3 bucket for high request rates.

How should the developer store the objects to meet this requirement?
